EAST SIDE UNION HIGH SCHOOL DISTRICT
	 
Item:  8.02
	 
	 
TO:
Board of Trustees
				 
				 
FROM:  
Chris D. Funk, Superintendent
				 
				 
PREPARED BY:
Juan Cruz, Assistant Superintendent of Instructional Services, and Kirsten King, Director of Instructional Services
				 
				 
SUBJECT:
Discussion and/or Action of Consideration of Petition of Proposed B. Roberto Cruz Leadership Academy High School
	 
	 
I.  Brief Introduction and Summary of Recommendation
	 
The petitioner in this matter is the NHU Foundation, which submitted a petition (“Petition”) to establish the B. Roberto Cruz Academy Charter School (“BRC”) dated April 29, 2013 and was received by the Board of Trustees on May 9th, 2013.  A public hearing was held at the June 11, 2013, Regular Board Meeting pursuant to Education Code section 47605(a) to “consider the level of support for the petition by teachers employed by the district, other employees of the district, and parents.” Mr. Edward Alvarez, President of the NHU Foundation spoke on behalf of the charter school. Pursuant to Section 47605, the Board, following review of the petition and the public hearing, shall either grant or deny the charter petition.
	 
The mission of the charter school as stated in the petition on pg. 4, is “’to accelerate, train and specialize high school students on a pathway to become credentialed teachers and work with historically educationally underserved students.’  A BRC graduate will possess a unique skill-set that will ensure their earning a meaningful high school diploma. A BRC diploma signifies their full qualification to pursue a post-secondary educational opportunity of their choice to become a California Credentialed Teacher.” 
	 
To achieve that mission, the charter school, in partnership with the National Hispanic University, will seek to decrease the amount of time needed to train and credential a new teacher from six years to just five, by completing one year of college by the time they graduate.
	 
The District Administration recognizes that the mission as stated in the Petition is laudable and, if successfully implemented, would serve an important need and provide an important benefit to the community.  However, as described in this memorandum, there are concerns regarding the financial assumptions written in the petition as well as concerns about the organizations ability to implement the stated college preparatory program. The petition states that BRC will use much of the same educational program implemented in Latino College Preparatory Academy Charter School (“LCPA 1”) a current charter school chartered by the ESUHSD and governed by the NHU Foundation.  Petitioner offers the track records of LCPA 1 as the rationale for opening BRC and the basis for BRC’s future success. The NHU Foundation would be the governing body for both LCPA 1 and BRC, as well as Latino College Preparatory Academy II (“LCPA II”), an additional charter petition submitted by the NHU Foundation for consideration by the Board.  Administration currently has concerns about the educational program of the NHU Foundation’s current charter LCPA 1 which raise questions and concerns about Petitioner’s ability to successfully implement the program set forth in the BRC petition and in the LCPA II petition as well. 
	 
For the above reasons and as described in detail below, the Administration recommends conditionally approving the BRC charter with the conditions stated in this memo. 
	 
II.  Standard for Review/Denial/Authorization
	 
Pursuant to Education Code section 47605(b), the Governing Board of a school district shall not deny a petition for the establishment of a charter school unless it makes written factual findings, “specific to the particular petition”, setting forth specific facts to support one or more of the following findings:
	 
The charter school presents an unsound educational program for the pupils to be enrolled in the charter school.
The petitioners are demonstrably unlikely to successfully implement the program set forth in the petition.
The petition does not contain the number of signatures required by subdivision (a). 
The petition does not contain an affirmation of each of the conditions described in subdivision (d). 
The petition does not contain reasonably comprehensive descriptions of all of the following:
	 
(A) (i) A description of the educational program of the school, designed, among other things, to identify those whom the school is attempting to educate, what it means to be an "educated person" in the 21st century, and how learning best occurs. The goals identified in that program shall include the objective of enabling pupils to become self-motivated, competent, and lifelong learners.
	 
 (ii) If the proposed school will serve high school pupils, a description of the manner in which the charter school will inform parents about the transferability of courses to other public high schools and the eligibility of courses to meet college entrance requirements. Courses offered by the charter school that are accredited by the Western Association of Schools and Colleges may be considered transferable and courses approved by the University of California or the California State University as creditable under the "A" to "G" admissions criteria may be considered to meet college entrance requirements.
	 
	 
 (B) The measurable pupil outcomes identified for use by the charter school. "Pupil outcomes," for purposes of this part, means the extent to which all pupils of the school demonstrate that they have attained the skills, knowledge, and attitudes specified as goals in the school's educational program. Pupil outcomes shall include outcomes that address increases in pupil academic achievement both school-wide and for all groups of pupils served by the charter school, as that term is defined in subparagraph (B) of paragraph (3) of subdivision (a) of Section 47607.
	 
 (C) The method by which pupil progress in meeting those pupil outcomes is to be measured.
	 
 (D) The governance structure of the school, including, but not limited to, the process to be followed by the school to ensure parental involvement.
	 
 (E) The qualifications to be met by individuals to be employed by the school.
	 
 (F) The procedures that the school will follow to ensure the health and safety of pupils and staff. These procedures shall include the requirement that each employee of the school furnish the school with a criminal record summary as described in Section 44237.
	 
 (G) The means by which the school will achieve a racial and ethnic balance among its pupils that is reflective of the general population residing within the territorial jurisdiction of the school district to which the charter petition is submitted.
	 
 (H) Admission requirements, if applicable.
	 
 (I) The manner in which annual, independent financial audits shall be conducted, which shall employ generally accepted accounting principles, and the manner in which audit exceptions and deficiencies shall be resolved to the satisfaction of the chartering authority.
	 
 (J) The procedures by which pupils can be suspended or expelled.
	 
 (K) The manner by which staff members of the charter schools will be covered by the State Teachers' Retirement System, the Public Employees' Retirement System, or federal social security.
	 
 (L) The public school attendance alternatives for pupils residing within the school district who choose not to attend charter schools.
	 
 (M) A description of the rights of any employee of the school district upon leaving the employment of the school district to work in a charter school, and of any rights of return to the school district after employment at a charter school.
	 
 (N) The procedures to be followed by the charter school and the entity granting the charter to resolve disputes relating to provisions of the charter.
	 
 (O) A declaration whether or not the charter school shall be deemed the exclusive public school employer of the employees of the charter school for purposes of Chapter 10.7 (commencing with Section 3540) of Division 4 of Title 1 of the Government Code.
	 
 (P) A description of the procedures to be used if the charter school closes. The procedures shall ensure a final audit of the school to determine the disposition of all assets and liabilities of the charter school, including plans for disposing of any net assets and for the maintenance and transfer of pupil records.
	 
III.  Administration’s Recommended Conditions of Approval
	 
1.     Condition #1:  Petitioner must submit to the District documentation from UC Doorways that LCPA 1 has the minimum 15 courses required to certify students UC a-g eligible by April 15, 2014. 
	 
a.     The BRC petition proposes to use the educational program currently in place at LCPA 1 as the bases for the curriculum at BRC. LCPA 1 has been in operation for 12 years and currently does not have the minimum 15 courses approved by UC Doorways to certify that graduates have completed the UC/CSU course requirements for admissions. 
	 
b.    LCPA 1 is currently working on obtaining UC Doorways approval of their courses but has not achieved this status yet. Therefore prior to opening BRC, described in the petition as a college preparatory high school, the course work at LCPA 1, stated to be used at BRC, needs to be UC/CSU approved. 
	 
Condition #2:  Submit proof of intended enrollment by June 15, 2014 for LCPA 1, LCPA II, and BRC.  Such proof shall include signed statements from parents identifying their student by name, age and grade level, and that they have enrolled or intended to enroll such student in LCPA 1, LCPA II or BRC. 
	 
a. There is compelling evidence and indicators that BRC will not meet its enrollment targets. The current enrollment of LCPA I – NHU Foundation’s existing charter school -- shows an under enrollment of 35 students. The current charter petition does not contain any indication that it will meet its enrollment of 100. The projected enrollment of the current charter LCPA I was not met, and next year combining both LCPA I, BRC, and LCPA 2 the NHU Foundation will need 335 more students to reach enrollment projections: 135 students for LCPA I, 100 students for BRC, and 100 students for LCPA 2. There is no documentation in this Petition that indicates any method or plan for achieving those enrollment goals but the NHU Foundation has indicated that they have hired a recruiter. Failure to achieve the targeted enrollment will result in adverse financial consequences to the Charter School.  The Petitioner projects a 100 student enrollment in year one and uses an enrollment of 105 students with a high ADA rate in the budget analysis in order to show a positive end of year budget balance.  
	 
b. The budget assumptions listed in the petition include receiving a facilities grant based on 105 student enrollment in year 1, 210 student enrollment in year two, and 315 student enrollment in year 3, along with 96% ADA. The actual ADA 3-year average rate for LCPA is 93.89% and as stated in “a” above it appears likely BRC will not make its enrollment projections. 
Administration reworked the 3 year projected budget based on a 100 student enrollment in year 1, increased revenue to include the new LCFF funding, and 93.89% ADA. See Attachment A. If BRC receives the facilities grant and makes the 100 student enrollment target, it will have a $25,671 positive end fund balance after year 1. If BRC receives the facilities grant but does not make the 100 student enrollment target, and only enrolls 80 students, it will have a negative $144,475 ending fund balance in year 1. If BRC receives the facilities grant but only enrolls 90 students it will have a negative $59,463 ending fund balance in year 1. Therefore proof of enrollment in all 3 schools would provide an assurance that BRC would likely achieve a positive budget and remain solvent through year 1. 
	 
Condition #3:  Submit proof that the NHU Foundation has acquired an appropriate facility to house the BRC school with appropriate proof of insurance by July 1, 2014.
	 
Condition #4:  Successfully negotiate an acceptable MOU agreement with the district by November 30, 2013.
	 
Condition #5:  Correct deficiencies in the charter petitions noted in the evaluation matrix submitted to the Board during these authorization proceedings by no later than January 30, 2014. 
	 
a.    Items concerning the educational program were missing in the charter proposal documents. These items have been submitted by the petitioners since the acceptance of the proposals and should be included in the charter document. These items include: Graduation Requirements, English Language Learner reclassification requirements, proposed school calendar of days, and proposed bell schedule. 
	 
b.     Other entities are referred to in the charter that are inappropriate and should be corrected for example reference to the to the SCCOE Superintendent on Pg. 119.
	 
c.    Other areas that need correction, such as measurable student outcome (required by Education Code), are specified in the Charter Evaluation Matrix – BRC, Attached. 
	 
	 
	 
FUNDING SOURCE:
Not applicable
	 
FISCAL IMPACT:
Not applicable
	 
RECOMMENDATION:
It is recommended that the Board of Trustees review and consider the proposed B. Roberto Cruz Leadership Academy submitted by Petitioner NHU Foundation.  If the Board determines to authorize the charter conditionally based on the satisfactory submission and resolution of the conditions stated above by the dates indicated above, then Administration proposes and recommends that the Board adopt the above analysis and factual findings in support of its conditional approval. On that basis, Administration recommends authorizing the charter petition based on satisfaction of Conditions nos. 1-5 above as described herein and that the Petition be approved solely on that basis for a term of 2 years to end on June 30, 2015.

Children of immigrants comprise 1 in 4 of all children in the United States and represent the fastest grown segment of the child population.  As such, children who have grown up in the United States, attended local schools, and demonstrated a commitment to succeed should not be limited by an immigration status they had no control over. Families are the building block of our society and culture; they should not be split apart.
	 
Over one million undocumented children under the age of 18 face limited access to higher education and only temporary limited access to higher education and only temporary legal means to join the work force.
	 
East Side Union High School District remains committed to working on the side of justice and equity for all, along with our community partners, including unions, civil rights, human rights and immigrant rights organizations, to pass comprehensive immigration reform that is not just for immigrants’ rights, but for the rights of all workers who are trying to make a decent living for their families.  East Side District, which represents the voices of many citizens and immigrants, calls upon Congress to pass common-sense immigration reform that includes a humane, practical path to citizenship for undocumented immigrants and the reform of temporary worker programs that exploit immigrant workers and lower wages and working conditions for all workers.
	 
The Board is asked to support and adopt the attached resolution in support of comprehensive immigration reform that includes a pathway to citizenship for aspiring citizens already in the United States.

EAST SIDE UNION HIGH SCHOOL DISTRICT
	 
Resolution No. 2013/2014-01
SUPPORTING A ROAD MAP TO CITIZENSHIP FOR
ASPIRING CITIZENS OF THE UNITED STATES
	 
WHEREAS, children of immigrants currently comprise 1 in 4 of all children in the US and represent the fastest growing segment of the child population; Children have historically been disregarded and often excluded in US immigration policy decisions; Children have few special protections under current immigration law and their best interests are often considered irrelevant; and
	 
WHEREAS, both children who are immigrants themselves as well as US citizen children with immigrant parents continue to face high rates of family separation, emotional trauma, economic instability, poor educational outcomes and limited access to critical services and programs; and
	 
WHEREAS, 5.5 million children in the US live in mixed-legal status families and are at risk of being separated from a parent at any time; half of California children aged 12-17 have an immigrant parent; in Santa Clara County, immigrants and their children make up 60% of the County’s population; and
	 
WHEREAS, over 1 million undocumented children under the age of 18 face limited access to higher education and only temporary legal means to join the workforce; and
	 
WHEREAS, East Side Union High School District (ESUHSD) believes in equity, access and inclusion and recognizes that a strong and vibrant democracy requires that all men and women, regardless of their skin color or where they were born, participate meaningfully in our society with full rights and equal protections; and
	 
WHEREAS, America’s future prosperity will depend on our ability to ensure that all children have a fair shot at achieving their full potential; 
	 
NOW, THEREFORE, BE IT RESOLVED, ESUHSD remains committed to working on the side of justice and equity for all, along with our community partners, including unions, civil rights, human rights and immigrant rights organizations, to pass comprehensive immigration reform that encompasses these principles and strengthens our democracy; that ESUHSD, which represents the voices of many citizens and immigrants, calls upon Congress to pass common-sense immigration reform that includes a humane, practical path to citizenship for undocumented immigrants and the reform of temporary worker programs that exploit immigrant workers and lower wages and working conditions for all workers; 
	 
BE IT FURTHER RESOLVED, that this Board urges the 113th Congress to swiftly enact comprehensive immigration reform that includes the following elements: (1) a plan for providing a clear, fair and affordable path to citizenship for undocumented immigrant who are currently residing in the United States, (2) family reunification, (3) prioritizing worker protections and immigrant integration into our communities; and
	 
BE IT FINALLY RESOLVED, the ESUHSD will continue to work with its students; staff faculty, residents and community organizations to promote comprehensive immigration reform based on the principles outlined in this resolution and will communicate this position to California’s congressional delegation.

SUBJECT:
Discussion and/or Action to Adopt Resolution #2013/2014-02 Close the Commercial Property Loophole
	 
	 
In the 35 years since Proposition 13 passed, control over school funding and policy has been centralized in Sacramento. California’s chronic budget crises have been passed down to school districts, which have been forced to layoff teachers and increase class sizes. Furthermore, the State’s primary revenue sources—personal income, capital gains, and sales taxes—remain volatile. According to the LAO, California’s revenue is 3.5 times more volatile than the State’s economy.
	 
While voter approval of Proposition 30 last year provides some relief, California still ranks 49th in the nation in per-pupil funding. East Side believes California could permanently reinvest in public education and ensure greater revenue stability by reforming Proposition 13 to require regular reassessment of commercial property. According an analysis of data presented by Evolve which was provided by the Board of Equalization, such reform would generate at least $6 billion per year for local governments in California.
	 
	 
	 
	 
FISCAL IMPACT:
Not Applicable
	 
FUNDING SOURCE:
Not Applicable
	 
RECOMMENDATION:
It is recommended that the Board of Trustees Adopt Resolution #2013/2014-01 Close the Commercial Property Loophole.
	 
	 
EAST SIDE UNION HIGH SCHOOL DISTRICT
	 
Resolution No. 2013/2014-02
Close the Commercial Property Loophole
	 
	 
WHEREAS, voters in the state of California approved Proposition 13 in 1978; and
	 
WHEREAS, Proposition 13 created limits on the property taxes paid by residential and commercial properties; and
	 
WHEREAS, residential and commercial property values in California are reassessed upon change of ownership; and
	 
WHEREAS, owners of commercial real estate have benefited under current reassessment rules in that if a corporation owning commercial property is sold or merged with another corporation, but the property it owns stays deeded to the corporation, ownership of the property effectively changes without triggering a reassessment of the property; and
	 
WHEREAS, corporations often avoid reassessment of their property by limiting the portion of ownership that changes hands to ensure that no single party owns more than 50 percent; and
	 
WHEREAS, property taxes are a stable funding source for public schools; and
	 
WHEREAS, since the passage of Proposition 13, the State of California has assumed a greater role in the funding of public schools; and
	 
WHEREAS, since the State of California has assumed a greater role in the funding of public; and
	 
WHEREAS, public schools in California face challenges educating a student population with vast differences in language, poverty, parental education level, and other social, educational and economic factors; and
	 
WHEREAS, modifying the method of reassessing commercial property would net needed additional resources for public schools; 
	 
NOW, THEREFORE, BE IT RESOLVED, the Board of Trustees of the East Side Union School District supports efforts to modify how the value of commercial properties in California are reassessed to allow for more regular commercial property value reassessment,
	 
BE IT FURTHER RESOLVED, that the East Side Union High School District supports this effort while protecting existing protections provided to residential properties,
	 
BE IT FURTHER RESOLVED, that tax revenues generated by modernizing how commercial property is reassessed benefit local schools and not accrue to the State of California as general fund savings.
	 
PASSED AND ADOPTED this 22nd day of August, 2013, by the Governing Board of the East Side Union High School District at its Regular Meeting held at 830 N. Capitol Avenue, San Jose, State of California.

SUBJECT:

Background:  At an election held on November 6, 2012, the voters of the District approved the issuance of $120 million principal amount of General Obligation Bonds of the District.  The ballot measure for the bond issue (“Measure I”) included a specific list of projects for which the proceeds of the Bonds can be expended.
			 
At the March 23, 2013, Board meeting, the Board approved and authorized Administration and Legal Counsel to proceed with negotiations for a ground lease transaction (and related agreements) for a portion of the proposed facility on Franklin-McKinley School District (“FMSD”) property on which an early childhood education center and child development center will be constructed and will be operated by Educare of California at Silicon Valley (“ECSV”).  The District has been engaged in negotiations with ECSV and FMSD for the construction of the center and professional development institute (the “Educare Project”), which is currently planned to be located within the District at an elementary school site owned and operated by the FMSD. 
			 
The financing plan for the Educare Project calls for the District to contribute up to $1 million in connection with a proposed lease transaction for the facility.  The District intends to provide the necessary funds from a portion of the proceeds of General Obligation Bonds which are issued under Measure I.
			 
Proposed Action:  Bond Counsel and District Counsel recommend the District seek a judicial validation of the use of Measure I proceeds in this manner.  Judicial validation proceedings are undertaken in the Superior Court, and are authorized to determine the validity of bonds or the expenditure of bond proceeds on specific projects.  In order to commence a judicial validation proceeding, the applicable provisions of the Civil Procedure Code require the Board of Trustees to first adopt a resolution authorizing the issuance of the bonds and the filing of a judicial validation action.  The proposed resolution is designed to satisfy these requirements.
			 
Because the final details of the bond issue have not been determined, the proposed resolution specifies that such details will be supplied in a resolution to be adopted by the Board of Trustees at a subsequent meeting.  Such details include approving a preliminary official statement for the bonds, approving the sale of the bonds, specifying interest rate, maturity and redemption provisions, and specifying other definitive provisions relating to the bond issue.

Measure I
